name: umoci
description: umoci is a tool for modifying Open Container images
description_good_justification: The description is given in the README section of the webpage <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/README.md>, along with the main wesbite for the project <https://umo.ci/>.
interact_justification: This information is included in the project's CONTRIBUTING.md file <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md> and also in the README <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/README.md>.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: This information is included in the project's CONTRIBUTING.md file <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI) and Free Software Foundation (FSF). The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI) and Free Software Foundation (FSF). The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Basic documentation is provide in the main README of the project <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/README.md>, as well as in our quick-start guide <https://umo.ci/quick-start/>.
documentation_interface_justification: The external interface is described through the manual pages <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/tree/master/man> which are kept up-to-date with the project itself. The format of images is described by the Open Container Initiative (OCI) image specification <https://github.com/opencontainers/image-spec> as mentioned in the documentation. We also provide reference documentation in <https://umo.ci/reference/>.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All development is done in the open, which means that all interim versions are visible in the commit log.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: This project uses Semantic Versioning, with each release being signed and tagged with the project owner's PGP key (including a description of the changes for that release).
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: This project does not have any publicly known vulnerabilities, however as stated in <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md> including such notices will be part of the review process.
report_tracker_justification: Users may submit issues through the GitHub issue tracking system <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues>.
report_process_justification: Users may submit issues through the GitHub issue tracking system <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues>.
report_responses_justification: This can be seen by the current state of <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues>.
enhancement_responses_justification: This can be seen by the current state of <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues>.
report_archive_justification: Users may submit issues through the GitHub issue tracking system <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues>, which includes a full archive of all issues.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: This information is included in the project's CONTRIBUTING.md file <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: This information is included in the project's CONTRIBUTING.md file <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: There have been no vulnerability reports received in the last 6 months.
build_floss_tools_justification: This project uses the Go compiler, and various tools such as make and bash scripts that make up part of a normal GNU installation.
test_justification: This bats uses two test suites. Unit tests are tested using the standard Go language test functionality <https://golang.org/pkg/testing/>, and integration tests are run through the bats test suite <https://github.com/bats-core/bats-core>. Both are free software.
test_invocation_justification: The test suite can be invoked from the project's Makefile <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/Makefile> which uses the standard go testing tool for unit tests and runs the bats testing tool for integration tests.
test_most_justification:
As part of our testing, we generate a line coverage profile for the entire project <https://www.cyphar.com/blog/post/golang-integration-coverage>. The total percentage of tested lines of code is currently >80% <https://travis-ci.org/opencontainers/umoci/jobs/221181536#L1846-L2074>, with plans to improve this in the future.

In addition, we test against a large variety of images to ensure that our code correctly handles different distribution idiosyncrasies correctly and safely.
test_policy_justification: This policy is described in the project's CONTRIBUTING.md file <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
tests_are_added_justification: All releases have their test runs publicly visible from our CI system <https://travis-ci.org/opencontainers/umoci>. All releases and commits to master have their test output publicly accessible at <https://travis-ci.org/github/opencontainers/umoci/builds>.
tests_documented_added_justification: This information is included in the project's CONTRIBUTING.md file <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
warnings_justification: The Go compiler does not emit warnings, and we use several linters to further ensure the sanity of our tools <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/v0.4.0/Makefile#L91>. All of the linters (golint, gofmt, govet) we use are free software.
warnings_fixed_justification: The Go compiler does not emit warnings, and our test suite will automatically fail if any of the linters we use produce warnings <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/v0.4.0/Makefile#L91>.
warnings_strict_justification: The Go compiler does not emit warnings, and our test suite will automatically fail if any of the linters we use produce warnings.
know_secure_design_justification: One of the primary developers (Aleksa Sarai) has previously engaged in security research and is aware of various design principles necessary in the design of secure software.
know_common_errors_justification: One of the primary developers (Aleksa Sarai) has previously engaged in security research and is aware of errors that can result in security vulnerabilities related to umoci, and knows how to mitigate and counter such errors. We provide information on our security design decisions in <https://umo.ci/reference/security/>.
crypto_published_justification: This tool makes use of the sha256 and several other hashing algorithms, which have all been implemented by Google as part of the Go standard library. Those libraries has been reviewed and tested by third parties.
crypto_call_justification: This tool makes use of the sha256 and several other hashing algorithms, which have all been implemented by Google as part of the Go standard library. Those libraries has been reviewed and tested by third parties.
crypto_floss_justification: This tool makes use of the sha256 and several other standard hashing algorithms, which have all been implemented by Google as part of the Go standard library as free software. Those libraries has been reviewed and tested by third parties.
crypto_keylength_justification: This project does not use public key cryptography.
crypto_working_justification: This tool makes use of the sha256 and several other standard hashing algorithms which are still considered to be secure. In addition, the algorithms used are mandated by the OCI specification.
crypto_pfs_justification: This project does not use public key cryptography.
crypto_password_storage_justification: This project does not use involve the storage of passwords.
crypto_random_justification: This project does not use public key cryptography.
delivery_mitm_justification: All project releases are delivered over SSL <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/releases> and have been signed with the main developers PGP key.
delivery_unsigned_justification: All project releases are delivered over SSL <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/releases> and have been signed with the main developers PGP key.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: Currently there are no publicly known vulnerabilities in umoci.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: Currently there are no publicly known vulnerabilities in umoci.
static_analysis_justification: Every commit in the project has several static analysis tools applied (govet, golint) as part of the CI process. All failures will result in code not being acceptable for merging. In future, we intend to run even more static analysis tools on each commit such as those listed in <https://github.com/mre/awesome-static-analysis#go>.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: govet is specifically written to look for "suspicious constructs" <https://golang.org/cmd/vet/>. In addition, we use gosec to find potential security issues (such as not checking error values). <https://github.com/securego/gosec/>.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Every commit in the project has several static analysis tools applied (govet, golint) as part of the CI process. All failures will result in code not being acceptable for merging. In future, we intend to run even more static analysis tools on each commit such as those listed in <https://github.com/mre/awesome-static-analysis#go>.
static_analysis_often_justification: Every commit in the project has several static analysis tools applied (govet, golint) as part of the CI process. All failures will result in code not being acceptable for merging. In future, we intend to run even more static analysis tools on each commit such as those listed in <https://github.com/mre/awesome-static-analysis#go>.
dynamic_analysis_justification: This is on the roadmap -- see <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues/335>.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Go is not a memory unsafe language.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We have various forms of validation (most notably relating to checksum mismatches), and our test suite validates that such attacks are being correctly detected. However, since we do not have any dynamic analysis suite (our test suite only checks statement coverage not branch coverage), this requirement is technically not met.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We do not run any such tools at this time.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: This tool makes use of the sha256 and several other standard hashing algorithms which are still considered to be secure. In addition, the algorithms used are mandated by the OCI specification.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: This project makes use of the free software CI system Travis <https://travis-ci.org/opencontainers/umoci>, and the actual test framework is the free software project bats <https://github.com/bats-core/bats-core>.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: To this date no credentials have been leaked in the main repository, and we have a policy to immediately invalidate any credentials if they have been leaked.
english_justification: All of the main developers are proficient in English and the entire project is written in English.
hardening_justification: While Go doesn't provide many hardening mechanisms, we do use -buildmode=pie to enable ASLR <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/v0.4.3/Makefile>. We also additionally have several protections such as making extracted filesystems world-inaccessible by default <https://umo.ci/reference/security/>, as well as working actively on protecting against container escapes (though this is something still being worked on <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues/277>).
crypto_used_network_justification: This project does not support network communication.
crypto_tls12_justification: This project does not use TLS.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: This project does not use TLS.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: This project does not use TLS.
hardened_site_justification: The necessary hardening headers are being set (see <https://observatory.mozilla.org/analyze/umo.ci> for an up-to-date report), but unfortunately our CSP has to include `unsafe-inline` for both `script-src` and `style-src` because the Hugo theme we use makes use of inline JS and CSS. However we do plan to move away from this theme to resolve the issue <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/issues/336> and our project website is entirely static with no private data.
build_reproducible_justification: umoci is written in Go which is a reproducible project <https://blog.filippo.io/reproducing-go-binaries-byte-by-byte/>, and we also have CI checks to ensure that builds are trivially reproducible. <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/v0.4.3/Makefile#L111-L122>
dco_justification: This project makes use of the Developer Certificate of Origin, and is required for contribution as described in <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>
governance_justification: This project has a well-defined governance model <https://umo.ci/meta/governance>, matching most other Open Container Initiative projects.
code_of_conduct_justification: This project follows the Open Container Initiative Code of Conduct <https://github.com/opencontainers/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md> and a reference to the Code of Conduct is included in a standard location <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md>.
roles_responsibilities_justification: The current list of maintainers can be obtained from <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/MAINTAINERS>. The list of maintainers is stored as part of the source control.
access_continuity_justification: This project is part of the Open Container Initiative <https://www.opencontainers.org/>, which is part of the Linux Foundation. The management of the project is under the OCI Charter <https://github.com/opencontainers/tob/blob/master/CHARTER.md> which allows the TOB to make executive decisions if necessary, and all relevant rights to continue the authorship of the project are explicitly owned by the Open Container Initative. Release keys are not owned by the project, but by individual maintainers (however maintainers may add their own release keys, and new maintainers can be added by the TOB in exceptional circumstances).
bus_factor_justification: Currently this project has a bus factor of one (Aleksa Sarai). However, we are working on improving this situation (Tycho Andersen is close to qualifying in this respect).
documentation_roadmap_justification: There is a documented roadmap in <https://umo.ci/reference/roadmap/>.
documentation_architecture_justification: There is a high-level architecture document in <https://umo.ci/reference/architecture/>.
documentation_security_justification: There is a list of security considerations and how they were handled in <https://umo.ci/reference/security/>.
documentation_quick_start_justification: There is a documented quick-start guide in <https://umo.ci/quick-start/>.
documentation_current_justification: This is part of the review process for new changes, as outlined in <https://umo.ci/meta/contributing/>.
documentation_achievements_justification: Achievements are listed in the project's README. <https://github.com/openSUSE/umoci/blob/master/README.md>
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: It is not entirely clear whether this is met at the moment.
internationalization_justification: At the moment this project is not large enough for anyone to have contributed to internationalise the documentation or other information.
sites_password_security_justification: The project website is not run by umoci and we do not store any passwords ourselves.
maintenance_or_update_justification: umoci currently maintains the latest version of the project, and currently new versions are backwards-compatible with old versions (requiring no upgrade path work). When we start releasing major releases we will document the upgrade path, and provide a transition period (where both versions will be maintained).
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: We have not had any vulnerability reports in the last 12 months, however if we do we will include them in the release documentation as we do all other contributors to the project.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: This is automatically done with gofmt, as described in <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>. This is done as part of our CI for every commit.
build_standard_variables_justification: We use GNU make which honors such build flags. We also provide additional build flags in accordance with the community standards of Makefile build flags.
build_preserve_debug_justification:
Our build system uses Go's '-s' option. While this does remove debugging information (and we don't provide a flag to not do so), all of the relevant Go debugging information is still present even when stripped (so this is not as significant of an issue). In addition, our Makefile is incredibly simple so modifying it is not a huge barrier.

[TODO: Fix this.]
build_non_recursive_justification: We do not have any subdirectory build systems, only a top level Makefile.
build_repeatable_justification: The Go programming language supports this natively <https://blog.filippo.io/reproducing-go-binaries-byte-by-byte/>. In addition, we have checks in our automated CI to make sure that the binaries are reproducible in a "trivial" fashion with `make local-validate-reproducible`.
installation_standard_variables_justific: umoci installs files onto a POSIX system, and thus "make install" (and "make uninstall") obey variables such as DESTDIR, PREFIX, BINDIR, MANDIR.
installation_development_quick_justifica: All project results can be installed with `make install` and all tests can be run with `make test`. Docker is used to make the test environment consistent without developers needing to install any additional programs.
external_dependencies_justification: The full set of external dependencies are vendored into our source code and can be fetched with our vendor.sh script <https://github.com/openSUSE/umoci/blob/master/hack/vendor.sh>. We plan to switch to vndr in the near future.
dependency_monitoring_justification: We monitor our upstream dependencies which are stored in the standard Go vendor directory.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: We make use of the Go standard vendor directory, and do not copy the code. The exception to this is the third_party directory, which contains code that we have heavily modified from other projects (however we track changes in the upstream versions).
interfaces_current_justification: We do not use deprecated or obsolete functions and APIs (this is checked by govet in the case of standard Go library functions, and external libraries are tracked for deprecation notices).
automated_integration_testing_justificat: We have an automated test suite run for every commit, as described in <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
regression_tests_added50_justification: Part of our process is creating regression tests, as described in <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: We generate coverage profiles for every CI run. The CI will fail if the coverage is less than 80% for any one of the images that we test against, and we do not merge commits that have failed CI <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/v0.4.0/hack/ci-coverage.sh#L32-L38>.
test_policy_mandated_justification: This is part of our policy for contribution, as described in <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
implement_secure_design_justification: umoci is implemented with secure design principles in mind. Details of the security model and considerations are outlined in <https://umo.ci/reference/security/>.
input_validation_justification: Input in the form of JSON and tar archives are all verified by the respective Go libraries, and in addition we do some verification of the OCI image before and while we operate on it -- such as verifying the CAS hashes match the files <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/v0.4.3/oci/layer/unpack.go#L255-L275> and <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/pull/282>.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The set of cryptographic primitives supported by this tool is currently limited by the OCI specification (which is exensible, but currently certain parts of the interoperability are not clear). We do provide multiple cryptographic algorithms for manifest generation.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: This project does not store authentication credentials or private cryptographic keys.
signed_releases_justification: All releases artefacts (the source code and binaries) are signed using the project's PGP keys. This process is also automated. The private keys are kept by the maintainers and are not publicly accessible.
version_tags_signed_justification: All git release tags are signed by the same key used for signing release artifacts.
contributors_unassociated_justification: There are currently two unassociated significant contributors (Aleksa Sarai and Tycho Andersen). See <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/graphs/contributors> for current statistics.
copyright_per_file_justification: Every source file includes the standard Apache 2.0 license header which includes the copyright holder and year. Contributors are encouraged to add their names to these headers if they make significant contributions.
license_per_file_justification: Every source file includes the standard Apache 2.0 license header.
require_2FA_justification: The opencontainers GitHub organisation requires 2FA be enabled for all accounts that are members, and thus all developers with push access must have 2FA.
secure_2FA_justification: GitHub provides TOTP and FIDO 2FA, which are both cryptographically secure.
code_review_standards_justification: Coding standards and requirements are described in the contributing documentation <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
two_person_review_justification: As described in the governance rules <https://github.com/opencontainers/umoci/blob/master/GOVERNANCE.md>, 100% of contributions require two LGTMs from maintainers before a change can be merged. For changes made by maintainers, they are allowed to approve their own changes meaning that their contributions require one *additional* LGTM from a different maintainer.
test_statement_coverage90_justification: We currently have a hard requirement of 80% statement coverage for all new changes, which are automatically tested as part of CI. In future we plan to increase this to 90% (the main restriction is that currently Go's error paths are considered separate statements -- and it's not always possible to mock all error paths, especially obvious error paths).
test_branch_coverage80_justification: There doesn't currently exist any branch coverage tool for Go -- only statement coverage is available. <https://github.com/golang/go/issues/28888>
security_review_justification: This project has not yet received any third-party security review.
assurance_case_justification: We have a security model and description of how this model is implemented in <https://umo.ci/reference/security/>. It will be updated as-necessary.

name: lxd
description: Daemon based on liblxc offering a REST API to manage containers
contribution_justification: https://github.com/lxc/lxd/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/lxc/lxd/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
report_responses_justification: https://github.com/lxc/lxd/issues usual response time is within minutes/hours.
enhancement_responses_justification: https://github.com/lxc/lxd/issues look for those tagged as Feature.
report_archive_justification: https://github.com/lxc/lxd/issues lets you access closed issues.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: https://linuxcontainers.org/lxc/security/#reporting-security-issues or through Launchpad (https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lxd/+filebug) for Ubuntu users.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/lxd/+bug/1584230 is the latest example of a CVE for LXD.
build_floss_tools_justification:
Makefile + Go is all that's needed: https://github.com/lxc/lxd/blob/master/README.md
Builds on Linux, Windows and MacOS.
test_most_justification:
Every feature is tested through system testing, unit testing is used when reasonable too and static analysis is run on the whole code.
Each branch is setup in automated testing to have all tests triggered. Contributors can also run those tests locally.
test_policy_justification: All features get their own section in the testsuite.
warnings_justification: Static analysis is run on all code. Go doesn't have much compiler flags we can use to do build time checks.
warnings_fixed_justification: Go doesn't issue warnings but all static analysis warnings are critical so must be resolved prior to tests passing.
warnings_strict_justification: All our linter outputs are considered critical and will prevent a branch from landing.
know_secure_design_justification: The project leaders, Serge Hallyn and Stéphane Graber both have considerable experience in secure design both in userspace and kernelspace. LXC and LXD are effectively security tools designed to allow for untrusted code to run on trusted systems.
know_common_errors_justification:
As mentioned above, the project leaders have considerable experience with secure design, kernel and userspace security as well as experience with common issues related to databases (SQL injection) and network based attacks. Go's design avoids a lot of the common security issues with some other compiled languages (buffer overflows, uninitialized pointers, ...). Our linters catch some of the more subtle issues and manual review is done on all submitted code.

Whenever possible, code is run after privilege dropping and we use kernel capabilities, apparmor, seccomp, cgroups and namespaces to reduce the attack surface of the code we run to a minimum.
crypto_published_justification: LXD uses the Go TLS library for its HTTPs implementation. Only the most recent and trusted ciphers are allowed with all legacy ciphers being explicitly disabled in our client and server code.
crypto_call_justification: We use the Go TLS library.
crypto_keylength_justification: We use an hardcoded default of 4096bit RSA. Users can manually generate their own key and certificates if they wish for something different but LXD itself always uses 4096bit.
crypto_working_justification:
All broken ciphers are disabled, only 4 very recent and safe ciphers are whitelisted.
https://github.com/lxc/lxd/blob/master/shared/network.go#L39
crypto_pfs_justification: Our combination of cipher and TLS config do implement PFS.
crypto_password_storage_justification: We don't have a concept of a user but when a password is used, it is hashed using scrypt.
crypto_random_justification: Handled by Go TLS which uses /dev/random as its source.
delivery_mitm_justification: https with client certificate authentication and either validates the trust chain to the system CA or the expected certificate has to be explicitly trusted by the user.
delivery_unsigned_justification: All hashes (for images in our case) are retrieved over https, the actual payload may then be downloaded over http, hashed and checked against the hash we got earlier.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: All known vulnerabilities have been resolved and properly announced (we get our own CVE number allocations from MITRE).
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: For critical vulnerabilities, we've usually been fixing them within less than two weeks after private disclosure of the issue and coordinate with distributions to find a suitable release date. No security vulnerability has been publicly disclosed without a fix already being available.
static_analysis_justification: pep8, pyflakes3, golint, deadcode, gofmt, go fmt, go vet, shellcheck
static_analysis_fixed_justification: No code can land without all static analysis passing.
static_analysis_often_justification: On every commit and every pull request.
dynamic_analysis_justification:
We haven't yet found a way to run a fuzzer against our Go codebase. We do occasionally run valgrind on the codebase, but it's hard to distinguish Go runtime issues from LXD issues.

We do however have checks for fd leakage, memory leakage, goroutine leakage, ... that are run in the testsuite.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We have extended logging which is visible and checked during CI as an alternative to proper dynamic analysis. As mentioned above, we do also have checks for a number of resource leakage as part of our testsuite.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Anything that's detected by our testsuite (mostly resource leaks) is critical and will prevent the branch from being merged.
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
Forum: https://discuss.linuxcontainers.org
IRC: #lxcontainers on freenode
ML: https://lists.linuxcontainers.org
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The only secret we have in our repository is a client certificate that's used in the testsuite, this is used to make the tests faster by not having to generate a new 4096bit key. This secret isn't trusted by anyone outside of the testsuite.
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: LXC - Linux Containers
description: LXC is the well-known and heavily tested low-level Linux container runtime. It is in active development since 2008 and has proven itself in critical production environments world-wide. Some of its core contributors are the same people that helped to implement various well-known containerization features inside the Linux kernel.

name: AtmoSwing
description: AtmoSwing stands for Analog Technique Model for Statistical weather forecastING. The software allows for real-time precipitation forecasting based on a downscaling method, the analogue technique. It identifies analogue days, in terms of atmospheric circulation and humidity variables, in a long archive of past situations and then uses the corresponding measured precipitation to establish an empirical conditional distribution considered as the probabilistic forecast for the target day. This method is used in different institutions for hydro-meteorological forecasting in the framework of real-time flood management or electricity production.

name: ruamel.yaml
description:
ruamel.yaml is a YAML 1.2 loader/dumper package for Python. 

It supports roundtrip preservation of comments, flow-style and mapping key order.
contribution_justification: The project is hosted on `Bitbucket <https://bitbucket.org/>` and uses facilities similar to Github for issues and pull-request.
license_location_justification: https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/src/default/LICENSE
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://yaml.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
repo_public_justification: https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml
repo_track_justification: the source is in a mercurial repository
repo_interim_justification: All developer commit are reflected in the repository at Bitbucket
repo_distributed_justification: mercurial DVCS is used, which has, AFAICT,  a superset of git capabilities
version_tags_justification: The process that creates, and pushes to PyPI, the installable packages automatically tags the source tree, as can be seen here: https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/commits/all
release_notes_justification: Recent release notes are in the projects README.rst in the ChangeLog section (https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/src/default/README.rst and https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ruamel.yaml ), older changelog items (currently more than two minor release versions "different") are only availalable in the CHANGES file ( https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/src/default/CHANGES )
release_notes_vulns_justification:
There have been no publicly know vulnerabilities, except for the danger of loading arbitrary Python objects/functions.

In ``ruamel.yaml`` new API this is clearly marked ( ``yaml = YAML (typ="unsafe")``). ``ruamel.yaml`` displays a runtime warning if used in PyYAML compatibility mode (this unsafe loading  is the default in PyYAML which doesn't generate a warning).
report_responses_justification: As can be seen from the unfiltered list of issues https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/issues, the vast majority of these has been answered within a few hours, and most resolved
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
Either by emailing or after contacting the author via a comment on stackoverflow. 
https://yaml.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#vulnerabilities

Details, e.g. on how to exchange a PR request via the authors private Mercurial repository on a publicly accesssible server (after providing a public ssh key) will be exchange off-line, depending on the circumstances
build_justification: The projects C code can be compiled using the ``setup.py`` provided.
build_common_tools_justification: The project assumes the use of ``pip``
test_justification:
The projects uses the widely used ``tox`` tool for testing its 274 direct test, and ~250 backwards compatibility tests (from PyYAML). 

Before a new version can be released the software is tested on all maintained versions of CPython (the latest released version of 2.7, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6) and pypy
test_policy_justification: First tests are added, that should fail without the changes, then the changes are made, and the added tests (and non of the already existing tests) should fail.
tests_are_added_justification: https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/src/default/_test/ shows the regularity of adding and updating tests
warnings_strict_justification: The typing check done on the packages .py files, is done with ``mypy`` which is run with the ``--strict`` option.
delivery_mitm_justification: ssh is used to communicate with the Bitbucket repository.
static_analysis_justification: Flake8 is used for code analysis. Type checking is implemented using ``mypy``
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: No **extra** rules beyond those build into the tools
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Several extra assertions are done during testing runtime.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The process of creating a new release includes full conformance to PEP8 and running ``tox`` on all supported Python versions. If errors are encountered the creation process is irrevocable terminated.
discussion_justification:
https://bitbucket.org/ruamel/yaml/issues  -- for bugs, enhancements
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/ruamel.yaml  -- for support issues
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
documentation_current_justification:
Documentation is in general kept in sync with the project, or used to define functionality, then as a blueprint for test, then implemented.

The documentation format allows for running of the embedded code examples as a standard practise.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: No project result directly used by end-users
internationalization_justification: Doesn have project generated text intended for end-users
maintenance_or_update_justification: Older versions available both from the repository and as installable packages  from PyPI.
